pages.text: Drepanosaurus unguicaudatus comes from the Upper Triassic, with fossils found in the Chinle Formation, New Mexico (USA); Zorzino Limestone and Dolomia di Forni Formations, Italy. It is a small drepanosaurid, growing up to 50 cm in length. They are known for having one huge claw on their index finger, as well as bearing a claw on the tip of their tail, used to grip onto tree branches.

No known skull has been found so far, but it has been inferred from other drepanosaurids that it may have had a bird like skull, which would have aided in picking insects out of branches. The generic name derives from the Greek words 'drepanus', to mean 'sickle'; and 'saurus', to mean 'lizard'.
